title.rendered: New Logo and Identity for Guardian Soulmates by MultiAdaptor

content.rendered:
Launched in 2004, Soulmates is the online dating service offered by British newspaper, The Guardian. 350,000 people have joined since and reportedly 1,500 new members join each week. Competing newspaper The Telegraph describes the service as “a sensible choice for urban intellectual types”. Earlier this month, Soulmates rolled out a new website and introduced a new identity designed by London-based MultiAdaptor.

The brief
To support a shift to an international growth strategy, Soulmates required a new brand identity to allow it to stand on its own two feet, while still feeling part of the Guardian family.

Our objective was to capture and express the personality and values of the Guardian to cut through the clutter. The brand also needed to reflect its premium positioning and be appropriate for a discerning, international audience.

The big idea
We defined Soulmates as a place where like-minded people who share similar passions, pastimes, quirks and irks, connect over the stuff that makes them, them.

Our response is all about these simple, special connections. This positioning differentiates from competitors who trade off features like the most intelligent algorithm, or just pure volume of users.

What we did
New logo, custom typeface, imagery, copy and iconography — an entire brand toolkit designed to reflect the big idea.

Extensive guidelines, including printed and digital example applications, brand strategy and user experience.

MultiAdaptor project page

The previous logo was a perfectly acceptable extension of the well-known Guardian logo and its slab-serif brand equity. The problem is that it felt like looking for love in the classifieds section of a newspaper. Kind of sad. By giving Soulmates its own logo it now has the ability to stand on its own and establish an attitude and aesthetic free from the guidelines of the news organization behind it.

I’m not 100% clear on what the panels in the logo are meant to be; perhaps paper sheets as if they were love notes? Profile pages stacked up? It’s the only confusing part about this otherwise lovely wordmark featuring a delightful “ou” ligature that makes you want to sing “X and Y, sitting on a tree. K-I-S-S-I-N-G.” The logo and extended custom font feature some stencil breaks that I’m not sure if they were needed but certainly look nice and add some ventilation to the letterforms. The matching icons are a great way to extend the structure of the font and are probably some of the most important aspects of the identity as they become the center point of interactivity on a dating site: join, search, message.

The identity is rounded out by fun, moody photography that, as the video reveals, has a groovy lens-flare coloring effect on top that ties all of the random images together. Amazingly, it works. You can almost feel the love chemistry at work. Compared to other well-known dating sites like Match.com, eHarmony, and OkCupid, Soulmates is remarkably advanced in its aesthetics and its sophistication makes you quite hopeful that you will, indeed, find your “urban intellectual type” better half.
